repository.title: Introduction to PMBOK 7
repository.content: The PMBOK Guide 7th Edition represents a major shift from process-based to principle-based project management. It emphasizes value delivery and outcomes over rigid processes.

repository.title: The 12 Project Management Principles
repository.content: PMBOK 7 introduces 12 fundamental principles that guide project manager behavior and decision-making, including stewardship, team, stakeholder, value, systems thinking, leadership, tailoring, quality, complexity, risk, adaptability, and change.

repository.title: Performance Domains Overview
repository.content: The eight performance domains are: Stakeholders, Team, Development Approach and Life Cycle, Planning, Project Work, Delivery, Measurement, and Uncertainty. These represent interconnected areas of focus.

repository.title: Stakeholder Performance Domain
repository.content: This domain addresses activities and functions associated with stakeholders. Effective stakeholder engagement is critical to project success and involves understanding needs, expectations, and managing relationships.

repository.title: Team Performance Domain
repository.content: Focuses on activities related to the people responsible for producing project deliverables. Covers team culture, leadership, high-performing teams, and creating an environment of trust and collaboration.

repository.title: Development Approach Performance Domain
repository.content: Addresses the development approach of the project, including predictive, adaptive, and hybrid approaches.

repository.title: Planning Performance Domain
repository.content: Addresses planning activities including estimating, scheduling, budgeting, and coordination. Planning is iterative throughout the project and adapts to changing conditions.

repository.title: Uncertainty Performance Domain (Risk Management)
repository.content: Deals with uncertainty, ambiguity, and risk throughout the project. Includes both threats (negative risks) and opportunities (positive risks). Emphasizes proactive risk management and response strategies.

repository.title: Delivery Performance Domain
repository.content: Focuses on delivering the scope and quality expected by stakeholders. Covers requirements management, scope management, and ensuring deliverables meet quality standards.

repository.title: Measurement Performance Domain
repository.content: Addresses project performance assessment and measurement. Includes establishing baselines, tracking progress, and using metrics to support decision-making.

repository.title: Tailoring Project Management
repository.content: Extensive guidance on adapting project management approaches to fit the specific context, including consideration of development approach (predictive, adaptive, hybrid), governance, and organizational culture.

repository.title: Introduction to PRINCE2
repository.content: PRINCE2 (PRojects IN Controlled Environments) is a process-based method providing a structured approach to project management with defined organization, roles, and procedures.

repository.title: The 7 PRINCE2 Principles
repository.content: The seven principles are: Continued Business Justification, Learn from Experience, Defined Roles and Responsibilities, Manage by Stages, Manage by Exception, Focus on Products, and Tailor to Suit the Project Environment.

repository.title: The 7 PRINCE2 Themes
repository.content: The seven themes are aspects of project management that must be addressed continually: Business Case, Organization, Quality, Plans, Risk, Change, and Progress.

repository.title: Organization Theme
repository.content: Defines the project management team structure with clear roles and responsibilities. Key roles include Project Board (Executive, Senior User, Senior Supplier), Project Manager, and Team Manager.

repository.title: Risk Theme
repository.content: Provides an approach to managing uncertainty. Includes Risk Management Strategy, Risk Register, and procedures for identifying, assessing, and controlling risks throughout the project.

repository.title: Managing by Stages
repository.content: Projects are planned, monitored, and controlled on a stage-by-stage basis. Each stage requires authorization from the Project Board, providing control points for decision-making.

repository.title: Product-Based Planning
repository.content: PRINCE2's unique approach focuses on defining and delivering products (deliverables) rather than activities. Includes Product Description, Product Breakdown Structure, and Product Flow Diagram.

repository.title: Business Case Theme
repository.content: The Business Case is the key document that justifies the project investment. It is created at the start, maintained throughout, and verified at closure to ensure continued justification.

repository.title: Closing a Project Process
repository.content: The final PRINCE2 process covering project closure activities, including verification of deliverables, benefits realization plan, lessons learned, and formal project closure.

repository.title: ISO 21500 Introduction
repository.content: ISO 21500 provides high-level guidance on concepts and processes for project, programme, and portfolio management. It is applicable to any type of organization and any type of project.

repository.title: Context and Concepts
repository.content: Establishes the context of project management within organizations, including relationships between projects, programmes, portfolios, and organizational strategy.

repository.title: Governance Framework
repository.content: Describes the governance structure for projects, including organizational roles, oversight, and decision-making processes that align projects with organizational objectives.

repository.title: ISO 21502 Introduction
repository.content: ISO 21502 provides detailed guidance on project management processes, expanding on the concepts introduced in ISO 21500 with practical implementation guidance.

repository.title: Stakeholder Management Process
repository.content: Covers identification, analysis, and engagement of stakeholders throughout the project lifecycle. Emphasizes understanding stakeholder needs, expectations, and influence.

repository.title: Risk Management Process
repository.content: Describes systematic approach to managing risks including context establishment, risk assessment (identification, analysis, evaluation), risk treatment, and monitoring.

repository.title: Quality Management Process
repository.content: Establishes processes for planning, assurance, and control of quality throughout the project. Ensures deliverables meet defined requirements and fitness for purpose.

repository.title: Planning Processes
repository.content: Comprehensive guidance on project planning including scope definition, schedule development, resource allocation, cost estimation, and integrated planning.

repository.title: Project Closure Process
repository.content: Formal closure activities including deliverable verification, administrative closure, contract closure, and knowledge transfer. Ensures proper project conclusion.

pmbok.title: Principles-based Standard
pmbok.description: PMBOK 7: Principles-based standard (12 principles) + eight Project Performance Domains; systems view and outcomes/value focus. Emphasizes tailoring and models/methods/artifacts.
keyPoints: Flexible models, methods, and artifacts catalog

prince2.title: Method-based Approach
prince2.description: Method-based (integrated elements = Principles, Practices, Processes) with a product-focused planning approach, explicit roles (Project Board, Executive, Senior User/Supplier) and stage-based control.
keyPoints: Five integrated elements: Principles, People, Practices, Processes, Context
Seven defined processes from start to close
Explicit roles and responsibilities (Project Board structure)

iso.title: High-level Process/Practice Approach
iso.description: ISO 21500 gives context/concepts; ISO 21502 provides guidance and detailed management practices (clauses 7.x cover planning, risk, scope, quality, procurement, etc.). ISO takes a high-level process/practice approach aligned to organizational governance.

similarities: All three require explicit governance, role clarity, planning, risk and change management
Stakeholder engagement emphasized across all standards
differences: PMBOK 7 is principles + performance-domain oriented (outcomes-focused)
PRINCE2 is a prescriptive method with defined practices/processes and named roles
ISO combines context (21500) with practice guidance (21502) and is intentionally neutral/adoptable
PMBOK emphasizes tailoring and flexibility most
PRINCE2 provides most structured process model
ISO offers most generic, internationally applicable framework
recommendations: Use PMBOK for flexible, principle-based guidance adaptable to any methodology

Apply ISO for international standardization and organizational consistency
Consider hybrid approaches combining strengths of each
Match framework choice to organizational culture and project context

pmbok.title: Risk Management - Uncertainty Performance Domain
pmbok.description: PMBOK 7 treats risk within the Uncertainty Performance Domain, emphasizing both threats and opportunities. It takes a comprehensive view of uncertainty management throughout the project.
keyPoints: Individual project risks and overall project risk addressed
Quantitative analysis techniques (Monte Carlo, decision trees) extensively covered
Risk response strategies: escalate, avoid, transfer, mitigate, accept, exploit, share, enhance
Continuous risk monitoring integrated into project work
Emphasis on risk attitude and risk thresholds

keyPoints: Risk Management Strategy defines the approach
Risk Register maintained as central artifact
Risk budget allocated for risk responses
Risk tolerance levels defined by Project Board
Defined risk management roles and responsibilities

iso.description: ISO 21502 defines risk management as a process aligned with ISO 31000 risk management standard, providing systematic approach applicable across all project types.
keyPoints: Risk treatment planning aligned with organizational risk appetite
Monitoring and review as continuous activities

Continuous monitoring and review emphasized across all frameworks

All recognize importance of stakeholder risk attitude and tolerance
Integration of risk management throughout project lifecycle
differences: PMBOK provides most extensive quantitative analysis techniques and tools
PRINCE2 has most structured governance with Risk Theme and defined roles
ISO provides most generic framework aligned with ISO 31000, suitable for any context
PRINCE2 emphasizes risk budget as distinct concept
PMBOK distinguishes between individual and overall project risk more explicitly
recommendations: Use PMBOK quantitative techniques for large, complex projects requiring detailed analysis
Adopt PRINCE2 governance structure for organizations needing clear risk accountability
Apply ISO framework for international projects or organizations seeking ISO alignment
Consider hybrid approach: PRINCE2 governance + PMBOK analysis techniques
Tailor based on project size, complexity, and organizational maturity

pmbok.title: Stakeholder Performance Domain
pmbok.description: PMBOK 7 dedicates an entire performance domain to stakeholders, recognizing their critical importance. Emphasizes continuous engagement and relationship building throughout the project.
keyPoints: Stakeholder analysis using power/interest grids and influence diagrams
Engagement assessment matrix (Unaware, Resistant, Neutral, Supportive, Leading)
Communication strategies tailored to stakeholder needs and preferences
Building trust and effective relationships as primary focus
Integration with other performance domains (Team, Planning, Delivery)

prince2.title: Communication Management and Organization Theme
prince2.description: PRINCE2 integrates stakeholder management within its Organization Theme and Communication Management Approach, with predefined roles for key stakeholders.
keyPoints: Defined stakeholder roles: Executive, Senior User, Senior Supplier
Regular stakeholder reviews at stage boundaries
Product-based planning ensures stakeholder focus on deliverables
Project Board provides senior stakeholder governance
Clear escalation paths for stakeholder issues

iso.title: Stakeholder Management Process
iso.description: ISO 21502 defines stakeholder management as a distinct process, providing systematic approach to identification, analysis, and engagement of interested parties.
keyPoints: Engagement planning based on stakeholder analysis

similarities: All emphasize early stakeholder identification as critical success factor
Continuous engagement throughout project lifecycle is universal theme
Analysis of stakeholder power, interest, and influence is common
Regular communication and updates to stakeholders recognized by all
Managing expectations is key objective across all standards
differences: PMBOK has most comprehensive engagement strategies and techniques
PRINCE2 has most prescriptive approach with predefined roles
ISO provides most generic, adaptable framework

PRINCE2 Project Board structure is distinctive governance model

Adopt PRINCE2 role definitions for clarity in governance and accountability

Consider PRINCE2 stage gates for formal stakeholder approval points

pmbok.title: Planning Performance Domain
pmbok.description: PMBOK 7 views planning as an iterative performance domain that occurs throughout the project, not just at the beginning. Emphasizes adaptive planning and continuous refinement.
keyPoints: Iterative and progressive elaboration of plans
Integration with all other performance domains

prince2.title: Plans Theme and Product-Based Planning
prince2.description: PRINCE2 uses product-based planning approach, focusing on what needs to be delivered rather than activities. Plans exist at multiple levels (Project, Stage, Team).
keyPoints: Product-based planning: define products first, then activities
Product Breakdown Structure (PBS) and Product Flow Diagram
Three levels: Project Plan, Stage Plan, Team Plan

iso.title: Planning Processes
iso.description: ISO 21502 covers planning across multiple processes including scope, schedule, resource, and cost. Provides systematic approach applicable to any project type.
keyPoints: Scope definition and Work Breakdown Structure
Rolling wave planning for uncertain environments

Work breakdown structures (WBS/PBS) are foundational concepts
Integration of scope, schedule, and cost is universal
All support adaptive approaches for uncertain environments
differences: PRINCE2 product-based approach is unique, focusing on deliverables first

PRINCE2 has most structured approach with three plan levels

pmbok.title: Quality within Delivery Performance Domain
pmbok.description: PMBOK 7 integrates quality within the Delivery Performance Domain, emphasizing that quality must be built into processes and deliverables, not inspected in.

prince2.title: Quality Theme

unique.topic: Shift from process-based to principles-based standard
unique.description: Earlier editions of PMBOK, as well as PRINCE2 and ISO, were heavily process-oriented—focusing on sequences of activities and deliverables. The 7th Edition is unique because it abandons this rigid process view and instead defines 12 broad principles. These act as guiding philosophies (like stewardship, tailoring, stakeholder engagement) that can be applied flexibly to any type of project, traditional or agile.

unique.topic: Performance Domains instead of Knowledge Areas
unique.description: Instead of grouping content into knowledge areas (like scope, cost, schedule), it introduces eight performance domains (Stakeholder, Team, Development Approach, Delivery, Measurement, Uncertainty, etc.). These domains interact as a system of capabilities—something PRINCE2 and ISO don't emphasize. This systemic design is unique to PMBOK 7.

PMBOK 7 positions projects as not just internal efforts but as strategic drivers of value. The 'system for value delivery' connects projects to portfolios, programs, and operations—ensuring alignment with business strategy. This strategic systems view is unique compared to PRINCE2 (which is more about governance) and ISO (which focuses more on practices).

While all standards mention teams, PMBOK 7 uniquely dedicates an entire domain to how teams function. It discusses project culture, psychological safety, leadership approaches, and emotional intelligence in detail. It treats teams not just as 'resources' but as a living system that impacts outcomes.

Engagement isn't just a task here—it's both a principle (guiding philosophy for all projects) and a performance domain with its own success measures. The uniqueness is that PMBOK 7 makes relationship-building and co-creation with stakeholders central to project success, whereas PRINCE2 limits stakeholders to governance roles (Business, User, Supplier).

Other standards treat 'risk' as a standalone area. PMBOK 7 broadens this by embedding risk inside the Uncertainty Performance Domain, which also covers ambiguity, complexity, and volatility. This holistic framing is unique—it forces project managers to think beyond measurable risks and consider unknowns, systemic complexity, and change volatility.

Tailoring has always been encouraged, but PMBOK 7 makes it central and structured. It includes a full top-level section that explains how to tailor step-by-step: assess context, design governance, adapt practices. Neither PRINCE2 nor ISO gives tailoring this much structured attention. This makes tailoring one of PMBOK 7's defining unique elements.

Instead of prescribing one 'right' tool, PMBOK 7 provides a catalog-style toolkit of commonly used models (like servant leadership), methods (like Kanban), and artifacts (like risk registers). This flexible 'menu' approach is unique—it empowers practitioners to choose rather than follow a strict template.

PMBOK 7 is the only standard that connects directly to a digital, evolving platform (PMIstandards+). This ensures the content is not static but continually updated with practices, examples, and case studies. Neither PRINCE2 nor ISO offers this living knowledge base.

Unlike PMBOK or ISO, PRINCE2 organizes its guidance into five integrated elements: Principles, People, Practices, Processes, and Project Context. This is unique because 'People' has now been elevated as a separate core element acknowledging that leadership, teamwork, communication, and organizational relationships are just as fundamental as processes and principles.

PRINCE2 is unique for its clear step-by-step process model (e.g., 'Starting up a project,' 'Closing a project'). While PMBOK 7 moved away from prescriptive processes and ISO focuses on practices, PRINCE2 stands out for keeping a structured, linear process journey through the project lifecycle. This makes it especially appealing for organizations wanting strict control and repeatability.

PRINCE2 defines a governance structure with four layers: Commissioning, Directing, Managing, Delivering. This multilayered structure clarifies 'who does what' at every level of authority. Neither PMBOK nor ISO provides governance in such a layered form.

Unlike PMBOK 7 (broad stakeholder focus) or ISO (sponsor/customer perspective), PRINCE2 assigns three formal stakeholder roles on its Project Board: Business (ensures project remains viable), User (ensures project meets end-user needs), Supplier (ensures technical delivery is possible). This triad model of governance is unique to PRINCE2.

Uniquely, PRINCE2 treats sustainability as one of seven mandatory performance targets to manage, alongside cost, time, quality, benefits, risk, and scope. Neither PMBOK nor ISO elevate sustainability to this level of importance.

PRINCE2 combines change control and issue management into a single integrated practice called 'Issues,' with a 5-step structured technique. This unification is unique—ISO and PMBOK treat them separately.

PRINCE2 uniquely formalizes 16 required management products (documents such as the Business Case, Project Initiation Documentation). These products act as 'control points' for governance and decision-making. The newest edition even adds a Digital and Data Management Approach, which provides structured guidance for how digital tools and data will be managed throughout the project.

Uniquely defines project context in terms of commercial customer-supplier relationship, providing specific guidance on adapting roles, plans, and practices when formal commercial agreement or contract exists. PMBOK and ISO acknowledge contracts, but PRINCE2 integrates this directly into its method.

ISO 21502 uniquely divides its guidance into two categories: Integrated project management practices (covering the entire lifecycle) and Management practices for a project (specific functional areas). This dual-structure makes it easier to separate lifecycle guidance from specialized practices, something PMBOK and PRINCE2 don't do in the same way.

ISO 21502 uniquely formalizes what happens before and after a project: Pre-project ensures justification, feasibility, and organizational readiness; Post-project verifies sustainability of outcomes and benefits realization. PRINCE2 has a closure stage, and PMBOK discusses benefits, but neither standard formalizes pre/post activities as explicit lifecycle stages.

ISO 21502 provides a full governance framework that clarifies how projects should be authorized, directed, and controlled. It uniquely assigns clear accountability to the Project Sponsor for achieving objectives. While PRINCE2 and PMBOK mention sponsors, ISO makes sponsor accountability explicit and central.

Like PRINCE2, ISO 21502 recognizes customer-supplier relationships, but it does so differently: it emphasizes how governance and team structures should adapt when both parties are involved. This makes ISO 21502 broader and more adaptable across industries.

ISO 21502 is unique in explicitly including societal change (not just organizational change) as a management practice. This recognizes that some projects (government, infrastructure, public health) affect society at large and must consider long-term social impact. Neither PRINCE2 nor PMBOK frame change management this broadly.

ISO 21502 uniquely guides organizations on what to consider before even formalizing project management practices. It covers organizational maturity, readiness for structured governance, and the ability to absorb change. This is absent in PMBOK and PRINCE2, which assume the project environment already exists.

phases.name: Initiation & Planning
phases.objective: Establish project foundation, clarify requirements, and create initial roadmap

keyActivities.activity: Define project vision and success criteria
keyActivities.description: Establish clear project objectives aligned with business value. Define measurable success criteria and acceptance thresholds.

references.note: PMBOK 7 - Stewardship Principle: Focus on value delivery
PRINCE2 - Business Case: Investment appraisal and justification
ISO 21502 - Benefits Management Practice: Identify and analyze benefits

keyActivities.description: Identify all stakeholders including product owner, end users, technical leads. Perform power/interest analysis and plan engagement approach.

references.note: PMBOK 7 - Stakeholder Performance Domain: Identification and engagement
PRINCE2 - People Element: Stakeholder representation (Business, User, Supplier)
ISO 21502 - Stakeholder Management Practice (7.12): Systematic identification

keyActivities.activity: Assemble project team and define roles
keyActivities.description: Assign core team members with clear roles (Product Owner, Scrum Master/PM, Developers, QA). Establish team working agreements and communication protocols.

references.note: PMBOK 7 - Team Performance Domain: Team culture and collaboration
PRINCE2 - Organization Theme: Defined roles and responsibilities
ISO 21502 - Organizational Roles: Team structure and accountability

keyActivities.description: Review existing requirements documentation. Create user stories with acceptance criteria. Prioritize backlog using MoSCoW or similar technique.

references.note: PMBOK 7 - Delivery Performance Domain: Requirements management and scope
PRINCE2 - Product-Based Planning: Product descriptions with quality criteria
ISO 21502 - Scope Management Practice (7.4): Define and control scope

keyActivities.description: Choose agile framework (Scrum, Kanban, or hybrid). Select development tools, version control, CI/CD pipeline, and collaboration platforms.

references.note: PMBOK 7 - Development Approach Domain: Adaptive and hybrid approaches
PMBOK 7 - Tailoring: Context-specific selection of methods
PRINCE2 - Tailoring Principle: Adapt to project environment

keyActivities.activity: Create release roadmap and sprint plan
keyActivities.description: Define release milestones aligned with business priorities. Plan first 2-3 sprints in detail. Establish sprint cadence (typically 1-2 weeks for small projects).

references.note: PMBOK 7 - Planning Performance Domain: Iterative planning and scheduling
PRINCE2 - Plans Practice: Stage plans and work packages
ISO 21502 - Schedule Management (7.6): Activity sequencing and scheduling

keyActivities.activity: Identify initial risks and mitigation strategies
keyActivities.description: Conduct risk brainstorming session. Identify top 5-10 risks (technical, schedule, resource). Define mitigation actions and risk owners.

references.note: PMBOK 7 - Uncertainty Domain: Risk identification and response strategies
PRINCE2 - Risk Practice: Risk register and management approach
ISO 21502 - Risk Management Practice (7.8): Identify, assess, and treat risks

keyActivities.activity: Establish quality standards and testing approach
keyActivities.description: Define code quality standards, testing strategy (unit, integration, UAT), and acceptance criteria. Plan for continuous integration and automated testing.

references.note: PMBOK 7 - Quality Principle: Build quality into processes
PRINCE2 - Quality Practice: Quality management strategy and reviews
ISO 21502 - Quality Management Practice (7.11): Plan, assure, control
PRINCE2 - Managing by Stages: Stage boundary authorization

phases.name: Iterative Development (Sprints)
phases.objective: Deliver working software incrementally with continuous stakeholder feedback

keyActivities.description: At the start of each sprint: Select stories from backlog, estimate effort, commit to sprint goal. Refine upcoming stories continuously.

references.note: PMBOK 7 - Planning Domain: Progressive elaboration and adaptive planning
PMBOK 7 - Development Approach: Iterative incremental delivery
ISO 21502 - Planning Practice (7.2): Iterative planning approach

keyActivities.description: 15-minute daily sync: What was done yesterday, what will be done today, any blockers. Keep team aligned and address impediments quickly.

references.note: PRINCE2 - Communication: Checkpoint reports and progress tracking
ISO 21502 - Communication Practice (7.13): Regular information distribution

keyActivities.description: Implement user stories following coding standards. Write unit tests (aim for >80% coverage). Conduct peer code reviews. Commit to version control frequently.

references.note: PMBOK 7 - Delivery Domain: Producing deliverables to meet requirements
PRINCE2 - Product Focus: Creating specialist products
ISO 21502 - Scope Delivery: Executing defined work

keyActivities.description: Automated builds triggered on every commit. Run automated test suites (unit, integration, regression). Monitor build status and fix breaks immediately.

references.note: PRINCE2 - Quality Reviews: Product quality checks
ISO 21502 - Quality Control: Ongoing quality verification

keyActivities.description: End of sprint: Demo completed features to stakeholders. Gather feedback on implemented functionality. Update backlog based on feedback.

references.note: PMBOK 7 - Stakeholder Domain: Continuous stakeholder engagement

keyActivities.description: Team reflects on what went well, what didn't, and what to improve. Identify 1-3 actionable improvements for next sprint. Foster continuous learning.

references.note: PMBOK 7 - Continuous Learning: Measurement and feedback
PRINCE2 - Learn from Experience Principle: Capture and apply lessons
ISO 21502 - Lessons Learned Practice (7.18): Identify and disseminate

keyActivities.description: Review risk register weekly. Update probability/impact as needed. Escalate new high-priority risks. Track and resolve impediments blocking progress.

references.note: PMBOK 7 - Uncertainty Domain: Continuous risk monitoring
PRINCE2 - Risk Practice: Regular risk reviews
ISO 21502 - Risk Monitoring: Ongoing risk assessment

keyActivities.description: Evaluate change requests against project constraints. Product Owner prioritizes new requests in backlog. Communicate impact of changes to stakeholders.

references.note: PMBOK 7 - Change Management: Adaptive change control
PRINCE2 - Issues & Change Practice: Change proposals and assessment
ISO 21502 - Change Control (7.10): Identify and assess changes

keyActivities.description: Update burndown/burnup charts daily. Calculate team velocity after each sprint. Forecast completion dates based on trends. Report status to stakeholders.

references.note: PMBOK 7 - Measurement Domain: Tracking progress with metrics

phases.name: Testing & Hardening
phases.objective: Ensure software quality, stability, and readiness for production deployment

keyActivities.description: Test end-to-end workflows across all modules. Verify data flows and system integrations. Test edge cases and error handling scenarios.

references.note: PRINCE2 - Quality Practice: Quality inspection and testing

keyActivities.description: Real users test software in realistic scenarios. Validate that acceptance criteria are met. Gather user feedback on usability and functionality.

references.note: PMBOK 7 - Delivery Domain: Verification of deliverables
PRINCE2 - Product Descriptions: Acceptance criteria validation
ISO 21502 - Closure: Deliverable verification and acceptance

keyActivities.description: Run security scans for vulnerabilities (OWASP Top 10). Conduct load testing to verify performance requirements. Address security findings.
Prioritize and fix critical and high-priority bugs. Conduct regression testing after fixes. Freeze features and focus on stability.

references.note: PMBOK 7 - Quality: Defect resolution and verification
PRINCE2 - Issues Practice: Issue resolution and closure

keyActivities.description: Document deployment steps and runbook. Create rollback plan in case of issues. Prepare production environment and access.

references.note: PRINCE2 - Plans: Exception and contingency planning

keyActivities.activity: Create user documentation and training materials
keyActivities.description: Write user guides, FAQs, and help documentation. Prepare training materials for end users. Plan training sessions if needed.

references.note: ISO 21502 - Closure: Knowledge transfer and documentation

decisionGate.name: Go/No-Go Deployment Decision
criteria: All critical and high defects resolved
UAT sign-off received from key users

references.note: PRINCE2 - Stage Boundaries: Final stage authorization

phases.name: Deployment & Transition
phases.objective: Successfully deploy software to production and transition to operations

keyActivities.description: Deploy software to production environment following runbook. Monitor deployment process closely. Verify all components are functioning correctly.

references.note: PMBOK 7 - Delivery Domain: Final deliverable handover
PRINCE2 - Closing a Project: Product handover

keyActivities.description: Closely monitor production for first 48-72 hours. Track errors, performance metrics, and user feedback. Address any critical issues immediately.
Train end users on new software features. Provide hands-on practice and Q&A sessions. Distribute user guides and quick reference materials.

keyActivities.activity: Transition to operations and support team
keyActivities.description: Hand over system documentation to operations. Conduct knowledge transfer sessions. Establish support processes and escalation paths.

references.note: ISO 21502 - Closure: Administrative closure and handover

keyActivities.description: Establish baseline metrics for benefits tracking. Set up dashboards to monitor KPIs. Plan for post-project benefits review in 3-6 months.

references.note: ISO 21502 - Benefits Management: Monitor and maintain benefits

phases.name: Closure & Lessons Learned
phases.objective: Formally close project, document lessons learned, and celebrate success

keyActivities.description: Full team retrospective on entire project. Document what worked well, what didn't, and recommendations for future projects. Capture lessons learned.

references.note: PMBOK 7 - Continuous Learning: Final lessons capture
PMBOK 7 - Knowledge sharing and organizational learning
PRINCE2 - Learn from Experience: Lessons Report
ISO 21502 - Lessons Learned (7.18): Disseminate to organization

keyActivities.description: Archive all project artifacts. Update documentation to reflect as-built state. Ensure all code is documented and repositories are organized.
Get sign-off from project sponsor and key stakeholders. Verify all deliverables have been accepted. Confirm business case has been achieved.

references.note: PMBOK 7 - Delivery: Formal acceptance of deliverables
ISO 21502 - Closure: Deliverable verification and acceptance

keyActivities.description: Formally release team members from project. Conduct performance feedback sessions. Recognize individual and team contributions.

references.note: PMBOK 7 - Team Domain: Team recognition and transition

keyActivities.description: Close any vendor contracts or procurement agreements. Final financial reconciliation and budget variance analysis. Archive financial records.
Hold project celebration event with team and stakeholders. Share success stories and key achievements. Thank contributors and recognize efforts.

references.note: PMBOK 7 - Team Domain: Team celebration and recognition
PMBOK 7 - Value delivery and stakeholder satisfaction
PRINCE2 - Closing: Project Board approval to close

tailoringDecisions.rationale: Small team size and short timeline require minimal documentation overhead. Focus on working software over comprehensive documentation.
tailoringDecisions.tradeoffs: May require more knowledge transfer effort at handover, but speeds up delivery significantly.

references.note: PRINCE2 - Tailoring documentation to project size

tailoringDecisions.rationale: Aggressive timeline requires frequent feedback cycles. Two-week sprints provide rapid stakeholder input without excessive overhead.
tailoringDecisions.tradeoffs: More frequent ceremonies and planning, but reduces risk of building wrong features.

tailoringDecisions.rationale: Small team with well-defined requirements doesn't need heavy governance. Product Owner and Sponsor provide sufficient oversight.
tailoringDecisions.tradeoffs: Less formal controls, but appropriate for project risk level and enables faster decisions.

tailoringDecisions.rationale: Essential for maintaining quality with rapid development pace and small team. Automation reduces manual testing burden.
tailoringDecisions.tradeoffs: Initial setup time investment, but pays off quickly through faster feedback and reduced defects.

tailoringDecisions.rationale: Team size doesn't justify separate roles. One person can effectively facilitate and manage with part-time commitment.
tailoringDecisions.tradeoffs: Potential conflict between servant leadership and traditional PM responsibilities, managed through clear expectations.

successFactors.mitigation: Conduct thorough requirements review in initiation. Product Owner available for quick clarification.
Secure 15-20 hour/week commitment upfront. Establish communication protocols and decision-making authority.
Select team members with relevant technology experience. Provide training if needed in early sprints.
Non-negotiable daily standups. Use collaboration tools (Slack, Teams) for asynchronous communication.
Empower Product Owner to make scope decisions. Establish escalation path to Sponsor for strategic issues.
Mandatory sprint reviews with demo. Interim feedback on prototypes encouraged.

characteristics: High uncertainty in requirements and technical approach
Medium team size (8-15 members) with diverse expertise
Significant R&D investment and experimental work
Stakeholder education needed on innovation process
context.tailoringRationale: This hybrid adaptive process balances structure with flexibility to accommodate uncertainty. It emphasizes iterative learning, fail-fast experimentation, strong stakeholder communication, and staged gates to reassess viability and direction throughout the project lifecycle.

keyActivities.description: Conduct market research, user studies, and competitive analysis to understand the opportunity and constraints
Generate multiple concepts, create prototypes, and evaluate feasibility of different approaches
Define product vision, success criteria, and high-level roadmap with flexibility for pivots

criteria: Budget and resources committed for next phase

Conduct usability testing, gather feedback, and measure against success criteria
Evaluate technical risks, scalability, and implementation requirements for selected approach

phases.objective: Build production-ready solution with continuous refinement

keyActivities.description: Implement features iteratively with regular demos and retrospectives
Conduct comprehensive testing including functional, integration, and user acceptance testing
Create user documentation, technical guides, and training materials

keyActivities.description: Release to controlled user group, monitor performance, and gather feedback
Address bugs, usability issues, and feedback from pilot users

keyActivities.description: Execute launch plan, deploy to all users, and monitor adoption
Capture insights, document what worked/didn't, and recommend improvements
Transfer product to operational team with documentation and training

Drives research, experimentation, and ensures innovative approaches
Manages technical implementation and development team
Ensures user-centered design and validates usability
Defines quality standards and ensures product meets requirements
Facilitates agile processes and removes impediments

Synthesizes user research, market analysis, and validation results
Collection of prototypes, test results, and learnings from experiments

tailoringDecisions.decision: Phase-gate approval process with pivot flexibility
tailoringDecisions.rationale: Innovation projects require validation points but must allow for direction changes based on learning. Gates ensure investment discipline while permitting strategic pivots.
tailoringDecisions.tradeoffs: More governance than pure agile, but less rigid than traditional stage-gates. Balances oversight with adaptability.

tailoringDecisions.rationale: Innovation requires significant upfront exploration. Investing 40% of timeline in discovery/prototyping reduces risk of building the wrong solution.
tailoringDecisions.tradeoffs: Longer time to production but higher confidence in product-market fit. Reduces waste from building unwanted features.

tailoringDecisions.rationale: Continuous user feedback prevents drift from market needs. Regular validation reduces risk of building something users don't want.
tailoringDecisions.tradeoffs: Requires more stakeholder time and coordination, but dramatically improves success probability.

tailoringDecisions.rationale: Combines agile flexibility within phases with stage-gate decision points. Provides structure for governance while maintaining development agility.
tailoringDecisions.tradeoffs: More complex than pure agile or waterfall. Requires team comfort with both methodologies.

tailoringDecisions.rationale: Innovation projects need someone championing creative thinking and managing uncertainty. This role ensures focus on innovation throughout the lifecycle.
tailoringDecisions.tradeoffs: Additional role increases cost, but critical for maintaining innovation focus and managing ambiguity.

tailoringDecisions.rationale: Controlled rollout allows real-world validation and refinement before full commitment. Reduces risk of large-scale failures.
tailoringDecisions.tradeoffs: Delays full launch by 6-8 weeks, but significantly reduces deployment risk and improves quality.

tailoringDecisions.decision: Lightweight documentation with emphasis on prototypes
tailoringDecisions.rationale: Innovation is better communicated through working prototypes than extensive documents. Focus on tangible artifacts over written specifications.
tailoringDecisions.tradeoffs: Less formal documentation may challenge audit requirements, but enables faster iteration and clearer communication.

tailoringDecisions.rationale: Innovation benefits from diverse perspectives. Team includes R&D, design, development, and business expertise for holistic problem-solving.
tailoringDecisions.tradeoffs: Larger team increases coordination complexity, but diversity enhances innovation and reduces blind spots.

successFactors.mitigation: Set clear expectations that innovation involves failed experiments. Celebrate learning, not just successes. Regular transparent communication about progress and pivots.
Build psychological safety in team. Use retrospectives to process change. Communicate that uncertainty is expected and managed, not eliminated.
Maintain clear 'true north' vision while allowing tactical pivots. Regularly revisit and communicate vision. Ensure pivots align with core purpose.
Recruit user panel early. Budget time and incentives for user participation. Use remote tools to reduce friction. Make feedback sessions valuable for participants.
Use low-code tools, reusable components, and proven frameworks. Invest in prototyping infrastructure. Prioritize speed over perfection in early phases.
Use collaborative tools for real-time documentation. Hold regular knowledge-sharing sessions. Maintain searchable learning repository. Encourage blog-style documentation.

context.description: Civil, electrical, and IT components, 2-year duration
characteristics: Large team size (30-50 members) across multiple vendors
context.tailoringRationale: This comprehensive process emphasizes governance, compliance, risk management, and stakeholder coordination. It provides structured controls for managing complexity while maintaining flexibility for technical execution. Heavy documentation and formal approvals ensure accountability and traceability required in government projects.

phases.name: Initiation & Approval
phases.objective: Secure project authorization, establish governance, and complete procurement

keyActivities.description: Develop comprehensive business case including cost-benefit analysis, risk assessment, and strategic alignment
Define project governance structure, decision-making authority, and reporting lines
Develop procurement strategy, prepare RFPs, and establish vendor evaluation criteria
Identify all stakeholders, assess their interests, and develop engagement strategy

decisionGate.name: Gate 1: Project Authorization
criteria: Business case approved by governing body

phases.objective: Develop detailed plans, complete designs, and finalize contracts

keyActivities.description: Develop comprehensive plans covering scope, schedule, cost, quality, risk, and resources across all domains
Develop detailed technical designs for civil, electrical, and IT components with cross-domain integration
Conduct comprehensive risk analysis across all domains and develop mitigation strategies
Define quality standards, acceptance criteria, and quality assurance/control processes
Evaluate proposals, select vendors, and finalize contracts for all major components

decisionGate.name: Gate 2: Execution Authorization
criteria: All plans approved by governance board

keyActivities.description: Execute civil, electrical, and IT work packages according to plans and specifications
Track progress across all domains using earned value and other metrics
Evaluate and approve/reject change requests through formal change control board
Conduct inspections, audits, and testing to ensure quality standards are met
Monitor identified risks, track new risks, and execute response plans
Monitor vendor performance, manage contracts, and address issues
Provide regular updates to stakeholders through formal reports and meetings

decisionGate.name: Gate 3: Completion Review
criteria: All work packages completed and accepted
Budget and schedule variances within tolerance

keyActivities.description: Test all systems together to verify integrated functionality across civil, electrical, and IT components
Conduct formal acceptance testing with client/stakeholders to demonstrate compliance with requirements
Commission systems, prepare handover documentation, and train operational staff

phases.name: Closure & Transition

keyActivities.description: Transfer ownership and responsibility to operations team with all documentation
Complete all contractual obligations, process final payments, and close contracts
Complete final cost accounting, close financial accounts, and prepare final financial report
Conduct comprehensive lessons learned sessions and create knowledge repository for future projects
Archive all project documentation per regulatory requirements and organizational policy
Conduct formal review of project performance against objectives with governance board

tailoringDecisions.decision: Formal stage-gate process with governance board approvals
tailoringDecisions.rationale: Government projects require accountability and oversight. Formal gates ensure proper authorization, budget control, and stakeholder alignment at major milestones.
tailoringDecisions.tradeoffs: Slower decision-making but higher accountability and transparency. Necessary for public sector governance.

tailoringDecisions.rationale: Regulatory requirements and public accountability demand thorough documentation. Ensures audit readiness and long-term maintainability.
tailoringDecisions.tradeoffs: Higher overhead but essential for compliance, audits, and liability protection.

tailoringDecisions.decision: Dedicated PMO with formal reporting structure
tailoringDecisions.rationale: Large, complex projects benefit from centralized project management support. PMO provides consistency, standard processes, and executive visibility.
tailoringDecisions.tradeoffs: Additional overhead but significantly improves coordination, reporting, and knowledge management.

tailoringDecisions.decision: Separate specialist leads for each major domain
tailoringDecisions.rationale: Civil, electrical, and IT require specialized expertise. Domain leads ensure technical quality while project manager coordinates integration.
tailoringDecisions.tradeoffs: Larger management team but necessary for technical competence and quality in complex multi-domain project.

tailoringDecisions.decision: Formal procurement and contract management processes
tailoringDecisions.rationale: Government procurement requires compliance with regulations, competitive bidding, and formal contract management to ensure fairness and value for money.
tailoringDecisions.tradeoffs: Longer procurement cycles but ensures regulatory compliance and defensible vendor selection.

tailoringDecisions.rationale: High public visibility and diverse stakeholder groups require dedicated focus on communication, public relations, and issue management.
tailoringDecisions.tradeoffs: Additional role cost but critical for maintaining public support and managing expectations.

tailoringDecisions.rationale: Public infrastructure requires thorough validation before handover. Extended testing phase ensures safety, reliability, and compliance.
tailoringDecisions.tradeoffs: Longer schedule but essential for public safety and long-term operational success.

tailoringDecisions.decision: Earned value management for performance tracking
tailoringDecisions.rationale: Large budget and long duration require rigorous performance measurement. EVM provides early warning of cost and schedule issues.
tailoringDecisions.tradeoffs: Requires additional effort for measurement and reporting, but provides superior control and forecasting.

tailoringDecisions.decision: Formal change control board with defined thresholds
tailoringDecisions.rationale: Changes in government projects must be properly authorized and documented. CCB ensures changes are evaluated for impact and approved at appropriate level.
tailoringDecisions.tradeoffs: Slower response to changes but necessary for accountability and budget control.

successFactors.mitigation: Ensure active governance board with clear authority. Regular executive engagement and communication. Escalation procedures for critical decisions. Maintain political support through transparency and results.
